subject: Cooking
title: Types of Salt: Not All Crystals Are Equal
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Types of Salt: Not All Crystals Are Equal.

hook.text: A teaspoon of table salt and a teaspoon of flaky sea salt taste wildly different. Same mineral, different impact.

buildup.text: Table salt is finely ground with anti-caking agents. Each grain is dense and uniformly salty.

discovery.text: Flaky salt like Maldon has hollow pyramid crystals that crunch and dissolve slowly on the tongue.

twist.text: By weight, all salt is equally salty. By volume, flaky salt is less salty because crystals have air gaps.

climax.text: Chefs use kosher salt for cooking (even coverage) and finishing salt for texture and burst of flavor.

punchline.text: The right salt at the right time changes everything.

quiz.question: Why does a teaspoon of flaky salt taste less salty than table salt?
options: Hollow crystals create air gaps reducing density
